title: 109_hr3918
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Energy Relief Act" terminates laws prohibiting expenditures for natural gas leasing and preleasing activities on the Outer Continental Shelf. Existing presidential withdrawals regarding natural gas are revoked, allowing for leasing areas for exploration, development, and production of natural gas. The "Outer Continental Shelf Energy Relief Act" allows for gas leasing of at least 75 percent of available unleased acreage within each OCS Planning Area in each 5-year program. Additionally, the act includes provisions for sharing revenues from these lease sales. Effective October 1, 2006, bonus bid and royalty revenues from Federal gas leases within State seaward boundaries under the Submerged Lands Act will be shared. 50% of bids and royalties from leased tracts within coastal State boundaries will go to the State, while the remaining 50% will be sent to the Treasury. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow for natural gas-only leasing, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, and outlining procedures for leaseholders. The amendment to Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows for natural gas-only leasing, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, and outlining procedures for leaseholders. The lessee must follow specific requirements if oil deposits are discovered during exploration or development, and all laws and regulations applicable to oil and natural gas leases also apply to natural gas-only leases. Existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to development under certain conditions. The Secretary may restrict development under a lease to natural gas and associated condensate only, allowing for natural gas-only leases without amending the outer Continental shelf leasing program.
